subtitle: Thinking Allowed
Conversations on the leading edge of knowledge and discovery with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome. I’m Jeffrey Mishlove. Today I'd like to talk about my friend and colleague Stephan A.
Schwartz. He is the person whom I have done more video
conversations with in the New Thinking Allowed series than any other
individual. If you look at the listings page and scroll down, you'll see there are 24
individual - at least half-hour in length, roughly half hour in length - video
conversations with Stephan. Sometimes I call him “Steven” and I've known him for 40 years,
but Stephan is the correct pronunciation. He tolerates people like me calling him “Steven”
from time to time. But the key I think that you should know is that he's one of the most
significant people ever to
appear in the field of parapsychology. I have enormous admiration
for his work. Of course, we have many differences.
That would be normal for a good friend and colleague, but I can't emphasize
enough how important his
contributions have been to the field of parapsychology.
So, I want to review them now. For those of you who may not know how to access the listings page,
let me say this. At the very beginning of
this and every other “In Presence” video segment, you'll see a link that says
click here, and it'll take you to hot links to every single “In Presence” video.
Well, of course, if you've done that you may know that you're getting the entire listings page.
It will take you to the alphabetical listing for Mishlove, but if you just scroll down
below Mishlove, you'll see every other person. When you come to Schwartz,
there you'll see the 24 individual
interviews with Stephan.
Let me highlight a few of them for you.
The first one I did with him actually was about his encounter
with the Edgar Cayce work. Edgar Cayce is widely regarded by some people as
America's most important and most brilliant psychic. For many years
I thought of him as being kind of trivial, kind of popular, but not of great interest to
parapsychologists, because the
parapsychology community of J.B. Rhine at Duke University and so on, thought very little of
Edgar Cayce. But, if you hear
Stephan’s account, you'll see that it's really quite significant. Not only that, in the
very first segment of the “In Presence” series,
I described a psychic dream that I had that changed my whole life.
Stephan's encounter with the Edgar Cayce
material was based on a
similar set of circumstances.
It wasn't a dream in his case, but he was going through an
existential crisis, when
another lady had a dream that brought her to drive through the Virginia countryside
and find him at a country estate where he was more or less wallowing in misery. That encounter
changed his life significantly. So, I have that in common with Stephan, and I think that's
a very important piece of my
biography and his as well.
Some people have said that I'm something of an expert in the field of applied science, one of my big
interests. But, Stephan is more than an expert. He's a major
contributor to the field of applied psi. I’d have to say, as I think about it,
I'm not sure that anybody has done more than he has in the area,
especially of psychic archaeology, but he's done a lot of research in healing. He's really worked very extensively
with remote viewing. He’s one of the founders of the International Remote Viewing
Association. Not that he himself is
particularly renowned as a remote viewer, but he sure has the ability to work with
others who have that kind of talent.
He's a rare person in his sense. He has
entrepreneurial ability. I know many of my viewers have commented on the videos and they refer to him as Dr.
Schwartz, but the truth of it is he doesn't possess a higher academic
degree. He’s not a PhD, he doesn't have a doctorate.
It doesn't matter in his case, because his
accomplishments exceed most of us who do have those kinds of credentials.
I say that out of
admiration and respect,
honestly. Of particular interest, I should think, for those of you are his
Alexandria Project
interview and also the video with him about
Project Deep Quest. Those are two examples of actual
expeditions that he organized and
financed and
conducted the research. He goes into great lengths about how careful
he was in that research, how he worked to bring in outside experts, how he
documented things
every step along the way.
One of the interesting things about Stephan is that before he engaged in any of his psychic
archaeology work he wrote the book The Secret Vaults of Time, an especially well-written book.
He reviews the whole history of psychic archaeology and it goes back some distance.
Then he concludes the book by saying, “Well, if I were to do it today,
this is how it ought to be done.” He lays out a
methodology for doing psychic
archaeology work,
or he might prefer to say
non-local consciousness
archaeological work, because I don't think he likes the term psychic. I'm not afraid of that term, but some people find it off-putting. In any case,
he then went out and
executed various expeditions based on the
methodology that he had published in The Secret Vaults of Time -
very, very important. I highly
recommend all of those 24 videos. Let me explain, about half of them are not related to
parapsychology directly, many of them about his spiritual attitudes. But also, I
have to say this: for those of you who may be interested, I'm very sympathetic to Stephan’s work at a
political level. Now, a few seconds ago I did an “In Presence” segment on
politics in consciousness,
and I said that when we talk about politics, if we're going to talk about it at all,
it should be based on facts. Now, Stephan
publishes and makes available for free,
an internet newsletter called the Schwartz
Report. You can go to schwartzreport.net and subscribe for free. I have been subscribing for years
and I recommend it for this reason: it's based on data.
He looks at factual data. He claims -
he shares my, I suppose, liberal bias politically - but he says he doesn't care about politics.
He cares about the data. He's interested in
statistics concerning what
nations, what states have the highest levels of
individual well-being,
the healthiest states, the states with the best employment, the states that have
the best track record with regard to the environment, the states in which there are fewer unnecessary
deaths due to gun violence, the states in which
children are healthier. Those sorts of statistics are meaningful to him in terms of
the communities that are
producing those results and how they do it.
I think that's a very good basis for developing political views and
frankly I think it's worth paying attention to no matter where you stand on the political spectrum.
That data ought to be useful to you. The focus on data is an important way to look at social
issues. The other thing I can say about his work is that
it's a warning
for us. Where do we see the worst results? Where do we see the most dangerous
signs of environmental instability, drought for example, and
certainly the rise of authoritarianism
around the world? These are trends that he follows. Even if you
disagree with his politics, I think if you're interested in engaging in meaningful
discussion, you want to look at where the facts stand. Now,
you might wish to disagree with him about facts. And the previous
segment of the “In Presence” series, I suggested that you know, every so-called fact is
theory-laden or cultural-laden, so yeah, there's room for disagreement.
As far as I'm concerned, you can't really have much of a discussion at all if you
ignore the facts that are available. So, I see Stephan’s work as
very complete. He addresses political questions. He has a lot to say about
spiritual growth,
meditation, healing. He's done some excellent research in the applied-psi arena, and
he also has theoretical ideas about how
parapsychology works. He's a model for me of an ideal
parapsychologist. I don't think very many people like Stephan come down the tubes
in order for anybody to replicate his work.
They have to have his entrepreneurial skills, his skill at actually organizing expeditions.
But it's my fervent hope that somebody
listening to this video right now
might be inspired to
do the sort of work that Stephan has done to replicate the kind of findings that he has produced. Because,
in my view, that's how
parapsychology is likely to progress.
So, I highly recommend that if you haven't watched those videos with Stephan,
they're important and I urge you to take a look at them. Thank you for being with me.
